body:
The prebuilt binary you got depends on openmp for parallization.  And we need to use the openmp enviroment variable to tune the performance.

The most widely used enviroment variables are:

OMP_NUM_THREADS=n 
Controls the thread pool size


OMP_WAIT_POLICY=PASSIVE/ACTIVE
Controls whether thread spinning is enabled
PASSIVE is also called throughput mode and will yield CPU after finishing current task
ACTIVE will not yield CPU, instead it will have a while loop to check whether the next task is ready
Use PASSIVE if your CPU usage already high, and use ACTIVE when you want to trade CPU with latency

You could also build from source and disable openmp.

Ok, I can see why now. But yielding all my cores of CPU, I can't agree with this behavior. 

And the OpenMP environment variables are used in runtime or build from source?
By default openmp works in such a way.  You could build onnxruntime from source without the "--use_openmp" flag, the it will be gone.

In fact, I do want to use OpenMP to tune the calculation performance. The problem is that I couldn't see the difference while increasing the threads number. My CPU has 12 cores and 24 threads. Increasing the threads number from 2 to 24, the processing time and CPU usage seem the same to me, nothing changed. Only when the threads number equals to 1, the processing time doubles and CPU usage becomes 100%. I'm also an OpenMP-programmer, these totally confuse me. I really don't know how to improve my application performance on CPU now.

See: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/master/include/onnxruntime/core/platform/threadpool.h#L66

When you SetIntraOpNumThreads to 1 , the tp parameter for that function will be always NULL. Then it will go to the lower part and use OpenMP for parallelism. When IntraOpNumThreads is not NULL, openmp is not used at everywhere, so the CPU usage is lower.

@JustLuoyu I had a similar issue forcing OpenMP to run on a single thread, and resolved it by setting the appropriate environmental variable _before_ importing ONNX Runtime. Perhaps the discussion on https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/3233 is helpful

This issue has been automatically marked as stale due to inactivity and will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. If further support is needed, please provide an update and/or more details.
This issue has been automatically closed due to inactivity. Please reactivate if further support is needed.

issue.title: The problem of low cpu usage

repository.name: server
repository.description: The Triton Inference Server provides an optimized cloud and edge inferencing solution.

issue.body:
**Description**
A clear and concise description of what the bug is.

**Triton Information**
What version of Triton are you using?
21.08 to 21.12
Are you using the Triton container or did you build it yourself?
Triton container released by nvidia.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior.

Describe the models (framework, inputs, outputs), ideally include the model configuration file (if using an ensemble include the model configuration file for that as well).

**Expected behavior**
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.

The problem of low cpu usage. Specifically, a 6-core 12-thread cpu on version 21.08 shows a top command of 600% usage, which doesn't seem to be using hyperthreading. All versions after 21.09 show that the usage rate is only 100%, that is, only a single core is used. What is the reason, I look forward to your answer, thank you
